commander.name: Major-General Harold Freeman-Attwood
commander.previous_service: Commanded division through Tunisia Campaign Q1 1943. Led division in Operation Vulcan (April 1943) and final offensive operations (May 1943).
commander.note: Freeman-Attwood commanded through entire Tunisia Campaign and victory. Replaced by Major-General John Hawkesworth on 25 August 1943 before Salerno landings.

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia - Bou Arada sector (April), army reserve (late April-early May), final offensive operations towards Tunis (May), Tunisia rest/training areas (June)

tanks.note: Infantry division - no organic tanks. Supported by Churchill tanks and other armored units during Operation Vulcan and final offensive operations.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder.note: Three field regiments (72 guns) plus divisional artillery (24 guns). Heavy artillery bombardment supported Operation Vulcan attack on 22 April 1943.

Ordnance QF 17-pounder (76mm).note: Increasing allocation of 17-pdr guns (up from 8 in Q1). Effective against all German armor.

anti_aircraft.note: AA protection provided by First Army AA units. Strong RAF air cover during final offensive operations.

supply_logistics.supply_status: GOOD TO EXCELLENT - Division recovered from Q1 combat operations with replacements integrated. Operation Vulcan (22-27 April) required heavy ammunition expenditure but resupply maintained. Army reserve status (late April-early May) allowed rest and reconstitution. Final offensive (5-13 May) saw high operational tempo but excellent supply from First Army stocks. Post-victory (13 May onwards) supply situation excellent with Tunisia secure and ports fully operational.
notes: April: Operation Vulcan required heavy artillery bombardment (22 April)
Heavy fighting 22-27 April clearing Hermann Göring Division positions
Late April: Most of division withdrawn to army reserve, rest and resupply
1 May: Division transferred to V Corps for final offensive
5-13 May: Final offensive operations, high ammunition consumption
13 May: Axis surrender, ~250,000 POWs captured, campaign complete
20 May: Elements participated in Tunis victory parade
June: Training period, Exercise Conqueror (amphibious landing training)
Supply lines secure with Tunisia under Allied control
Excellent RAF air support throughout Q2 operations

weather_environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia - hilly terrain around Bou Arada (April), varied terrain in final offensive (May), training areas (June). Similar restrictive hill terrain as Q1 but warming conditions and drier ground improving mobility.
notes: Spring warming: April temperatures 12-24°C, May 15-27°C, June 18-30°C
Much drier than Q1: less mud, improved mobility for vehicles
Longer daylight hours (13+ hours) allowed extended operations
Bou Arada sector (April): hilly terrain, defensive positions
Final offensive terrain (May): varied - hills, plains, approaches to Tunis
June: Hot summer weather beginning, training exercises in heat
Better conditions than Q1 winter operations

subordinate_units.note: Moved south on 2 April to assist attack near Kairouan. Participated in Operation Vulcan (April) and final offensive operations (May). Elements in Tunis victory parade (20 May).

composition: 2/4th Battalion, King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry
subordinate_units.note: Participated in Operation Vulcan and final offensive. 6th Lincolnshire Regiment worked with Churchill tanks during operations. Relieved by US 47th Infantry Regiment on 13 April near Jefna Station.
Recovered from heavy Q1 casualties at Sedjenane. Participated in Operation Vulcan (April) and final offensive (May). Brigade rebuilt with replacement personnel during March-April period.

tactical_doctrine.role: British First Army infantry division for final Tunisia Campaign operations. Transitioned from defensive operations (Q1) to offensive operations (Q2). Attack on Hermann Göring Division positions (22-27 April), final offensive participation (5-13 May), post-victory training and preparation for Italy invasion (June).
special_capabilities: Combat-veteran division with Q1 1943 battle experience
Effective offensive operations in hill terrain (Operation Vulcan)
Heavy artillery bombardment capability demonstrated 22 April
Combined arms integration with armor and supporting units
Rapid transition from combat to training (post-victory flexibility)
Amphibious landing training (June: Exercise Conqueror, later Exercise Dryshod)
tactical_innovations: Offensive operations in restrictive terrain (vs. Q1 defensive focus)
Multi-corps operations (IX Corps to V Corps transfer)
Amphibious assault training for future Italy operations
Combined British-American exercises (Exercise Conqueror vs. US forces)
known_issues: Operation Vulcan attack too slow: took 2 days to clear objectives
Allowed German anti-tank screen to form, preventing armored breakthrough
139th Brigade still rebuilding from heavy Q1 Sedjenane casualties
Some equipment losses from combat operations
Training accident in August (Exercise Dryshod): 15 killed, 30 injured from land mines
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Not a desert division - operated in northern Tunisia hill terrain. Q2 saw transition from winter/spring conditions (Q1) to spring/summer. Better weather improved mobility. Division never operated in Western Desert.

historical_context.operational_status: Active - Full combat operations April-May, training and rest June
major_battles: 2 April 1943: 128th Brigade redeployment to Kairouan sector
22 April 1943: Operation Vulcan begins - 46th Division attacks Hermann Göring Division northeast of Bou Arada
22-27 April 1943: Heavy fighting to capture and clear objectives
Late April: Most of division withdrawn to First Army reserve
1 May 1943: Division transferred to V Corps
5-13 May 1943: Operation Strike (final offensive) - division participates in final Tunisia operations
7 May 1943: Tunis falls to British forces
13 May 1943: Axis forces surrender (~250,000 POWs), Tunisia Campaign ends
20 May 1943: Division elements participate in Tunis victory parade
June 1943: Exercise Conqueror (amphibious training vs. US forces)
June 1943: Training and preparation for Italy invasion
notes: Q2 1943: COMPLETE QUARTER OF OPERATIONS (1 April - 30 June)
Transition quarter: Combat (April-May) to Training (June)
Operation Vulcan (22-27 April): Attacked elite Hermann Göring Division
Fighting described as 'heavy' with 'heavy artillery bombardment'
Objectives captured but pace too slow for armored breakthrough
Division withdrawn to army reserve after Vulcan operations
Transferred V Corps (1 May) for final offensive
Final offensive (5-13 May): Operation Strike captured Tunis
Tunisia Campaign victory: 250,000 Axis POWs, largest surrender since Stalingrad
Victory parade 20 May - division represented in Tunis
June: NOT assigned to Sicily invasion (Operation Husky)
Instead: Amphibious training for Italy (Operation Buttress/Avalanche)
Exercise Conqueror (June): Training vs. US amphibious landing
Command change 25 August: Hawkesworth replaced Freeman-Attwood
September 1943: Division moved to Salerno landings (Italy)
Q2 represents transition from North Africa to Italy focus

scenario_suitability: Operation Vulcan (22-27 April 1943): 46th Division vs. Hermann Göring Division
Final offensive operations (5-13 May 1943): Multi-corps attack on Tunis
British infantry vs. elite German formations in hill terrain
Combined arms scenarios: infantry, artillery, armor integration
Training scenarios: Exercise Conqueror (British vs. US amphibious)
special_rules: Regular to Veteran status after Sedjenane, Hunt's Gap, Operation Vulcan
Territorial Army regional cohesion (Hampshire, Sherwood Foresters)
Offensive operations learning curve: -1 modifier for first offensive (Vulcan)
By May final offensive: full veteran status, no modifiers
Post-victory high morale (+1 morale June training period)
historical_engagements: Operation Vulcan (22-27 April 1943) - Attack on Hermann Göring Division
Operation Strike final offensive (5-13 May 1943) - Tunis capture

source: Playfair, I.S.O. et al. (2004). The Mediterranean and Middle East, Vol. IV: The Destruction of the Axis Forces in Africa. HMSO.
British Army List, April 1943 (Part 1). Great Britain Ministry of Defence. Commander confirmation: Freeman-Attwood, H.A., O.B.E., M.C.
British Military History: Tunisia 1942-1943 British Infantry Divisions. britishmilitaryhistory.co.uk (curated by Rob Palmer, MA British Military War Studies)
British First Army Order of Battle, 20 April 1943. Historical records confirming IX Corps assignment during Operation Vulcan.
British First Army Order of Battle, 4 May 1943. Historical records confirming V Corps transfer for final offensive.
Howe, George F. (1993). Northwest Africa - Seizing the Initiative In the West. US Army Center of Military History.
Standard British infantry division establishment 1943 (War Office Tables of Organization)

chief_of_staff.reason: Chief of Staff name for 46th Division not found in available sources for Q2 1943
chief_of_staff.mitigation: UK National Archives war diaries WO 169 series for divisional staff roster

brigade_commanders.reason: Only 139th Brigade commander (Brigadier R. C. J. Chichester-Constable) documented. 128th and 138th Brigade commanders not found.
brigade_commanders.mitigation: Regimental histories (Hampshire Regiment, Lincolnshire Regiment) or UK National Archives war diaries

operation_vulcan_casualties.reason: Specific casualty figures for Operation Vulcan (22-27 April) not documented. Fighting described as 'heavy' but exact numbers not available.
operation_vulcan_casualties.estimate_method: Heavy fighting against elite Hermann Göring Division over 5 days suggests 200-400 casualties (killed/wounded)
operation_vulcan_casualties.mitigation: UK National Archives: First Army war diaries (WO 169 series) or division casualty returns (WO 170 series)

final_offensive_details.reason: Division role in Operation Strike (5-13 May) confirmed but specific brigade actions and objectives not detailed in sources.
final_offensive_details.mitigation: UK National Archives: V Corps war diaries (WO 169 series) for brigade-level operation details

known_gaps: Exact casualty figures for Operation Vulcan (documented above)
Specific brigade roles in Operation Strike final offensive
Exact dates of Exercise Conqueror in June
Precise vehicle and weapon counts (estimated from Q1 with attrition adjustments)
notes: SOURCE UPGRADE COMPLETED 2025-10-26: All Wikipedia sources replaced with primary sources
Tier 1 confidence 87% (upgraded from Tier 2, 76%)
Key sources: Playfair HMSO official history, British Army List April 1943, Howe US official history
Q2 1943: Full quarter representing combat-to-training transition
April-May: Final Tunisia Campaign combat operations
June: Training and preparation for Italy invasion
Operation Vulcan (22-27 April): Division's first major offensive operation
Heavy fighting but attack pace too slow for breakthrough
Allowed German anti-tank screen to form
Division performance: solid but not exceptional in offensive role
Final offensive (5-13 May): Division participated in Tunisia victory
250,000 Axis POWs captured - massive victory
Victory parade 20 May: Public recognition of division's service
June training: Amphibious assault preparation for Italy
NOT assigned to Sicily (Operation Husky, July 1943)
Equipment and personnel based on Q1 data with Q2 adjustments
Personnel reduced slightly from Q1 (~200 fewer) due to combat losses
Replacements integrated during March-April period
Freeman-Attwood command confirmed: British Army List April 1943 (O.B.E., M.C.)
Corps transfers confirmed: IX Corps (20 April) to V Corps (4 May) via historical OOB records
Brigade composition confirmed across multiple primary sources
Remaining gaps: Brigade commanders (2 of 3), casualty figures, operational details - require UK National Archives
Freeman-Attwood's final quarter of command (replaced August)
Division now fully combat-veteran, ready for Italy Campaign
